description.text:
These are the STL files to make your own sweet talking box. The instructions on how to make your own can be found here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Sweet-Talking-Box-How-to-Make-Your-Own/

This mount fits the body of the Logitech C910 once the original mounting hardware is removed. The mount fits over the back of the camera and can be secured into place using a M4x22 bolt. There is also a flange that the camera fits into on the mount, this limits X/Y jitter quite a bit when the camera moves. Between this and the bolt the camera stays pretty darn secure. I used the mount to attach the camera to a "TERTIAL Work Lamp" from IKEA which runs around $9. It makes a great camera jig and unobtrusive desk mount for recording Makerbot prints or anything else really. More details about this build and photos on my blog post here: http://thenewhobbyist.com/2011/10/9-webcam-jig/

• Remove original mounting hardware from webcam
  • Print mount
  • Secure mount to camera using M4x25
  • Bolt the mount to something awesome and record away!

remixed_from.title: V1 + V2.0 Scalar - Electronic Box for MEGA+RAMPS+LCD2004

description.text: This box/casing for Arduino Mega 2560 and Ramps 1.4 is a minimalistic version of the Scalar - Electronic Box for MEGA+RAMPS+LCD2004 : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:945299

• It's compatible with 80mm fans.
  • Can hold both Ramps 1.4 and Arduino Mega boards.
  • The 80mm fan is blowing directly over the Stepper motor drivers and the power transistors
  • The 80mm fan choise is because these kind of fans are easy to find and often provide a very nice and strong airflow compared to 40mm fans.
    Also the size of the fan is compatible with the Ramps width making it suitable for this box.
    If you want to use 120mm or other fan sizes you can download fan convertion adaptors parts such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21112
  • The back plate has special holes for LCD2004 wires and also provide some holes for Airflow
  • The base holes are 4mm in diameter, so you can use 3.5mm wood screws or M3/M4 screws to hold it on any surface you need.
  • This box is designed to be lay down, and the holding holes are made to be attached on wood plate using 3.5x10 wood screws with flat head.
  • Side holes allow to insert wires to the Ramps board.

description.header: What you will need - Nuts and bolts:
description.text:
You will basically need a bunch of M3x8 screws to assemble all the faces of the box.
Also you will need 4 M3x10mm screws to attach the top of the box.
You can also use glue to seal the sides togather, superglue is working very well.
What we do is that we are using both screws and glue.
The glue is for long term use and the screws help the keep the parts together while the glue is drying.
Once the glue is dry you should be able to remove the screws if you want to reuse them. If you want the 2 sides to have holes, you can print a symetrical version of the left side panel. Also a plain top is available if you don't need any fans. 3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

title: GEEETECH G2 G2S delta printer 40mm fan support for filament cooler

description.text:
This is my first try for a fan support to cool PLA filament on a G2/G2S Geeetech delta printer. It is intended to use one of the useless extruder fan to make a useful cooling duct. It is yet in development, so there is known issues :
  • To install it you have to remove two diagonal rods and use the same screw to attach the fan support. As there is not much space between brackets this is quite difficult. You will need M3 x20 screw and M3 nut. You may want to protect the fan with a grid : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1171303 .
    • .
    Printed with support (remember I did not have filament cooling yet). The small version (fan_mount_3_g2s.stl) works better for hot end 2 or G2 improvements from the initial version :
  • better flow direction
  • access to the 4 screws to fix the fan
  • groove fixing allowing a +- 1mm for height adjustment
    • I did not tested it yet, all comments are welcome ! The long version cool the two filaments of the G2S. Printed and verified improve the printing but should not be used for the 2 or Three first layers (risk of warping).
    Improvements from the initial version :
  • better air flow direction (but could be yet improved)
  • all screws functional to fix the fan
  • air duct to the two filaments
  • groove fixing allowing a +- 1mm for height adjustment
    • The new version (fan_mount_g2s_long_2.stl) have an improved air flow control

author: p_hervier

description.text: This is a derivative of 'Rose' by Bratskbars. The original STL file consisted of 13 intersecting meshes which made it non-sliceable. 3DCoat was used to convert the meshes to voxels and fill the hole in the back. The complete object was then exported to a good quality printable STL. Blender was used to split the meshes into the flower and leaves groups. Then 3DCoat was used to import the flower and leaves meshes, voxelizing them, filling the hole in the back and using a boolean operation to cut off the part of the leaves that intersects the flower. Then the flower and leaves objects were exported to two perfectly sliceable STL files. The flower and the leaves should fit together perfectly and are glued together. The use of 3DCoat was explained on the 3D Printing Today podcast (Link) episode 107 and further. Highly recommended!

author: herrero_1

description.text:
This is a variant of the Tripteron and the Quadrupteron. (http://robot.gmc.ulaval.ca/en/research/theme104.html) Following that naming scheme I had to call it the Sextupteron for a 6 degree of freedom version. You could use this for 3D printing on surfaces that aren't flat, for an assembly robot, print with layers that aren't parallel to the xy-plane, printing extreme overhangs, negative overhangs, etc. Video:
http://youtu.be/2kXdsU2bBp0

Development Forum:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?178,229935 This is almost a complete design. I still need to pick magnets for the central hub. I also need to add mounting holes and a bowden tube clamp onto the the central hub. I also need to work on the pulley/idler assembly. Specification:
Outside Dimensions: 500mm cube
Print Dimensions: 325mm cube with the right arms and bigger if you tilt the hot end out to get past the traditional edge. In its current configuration it can do a 200mm cube.
Allowable Tilt: It depends but you usually have 116 degree range to move in. In the center you can do +/- 58 degrees. It isn't always symmetric. On the edges, you can flare out more than you can pull in. Rough BOM:
12 500mmx75mm identical pieces made from the flat stock of your choice.
8 unique plastic pieces.
45 plastic pieces
6 12mm x 510mm rods
12 LM12LUU bearings
8 608 bearings
6 605 bearings
6 185+/- tooth xl belts .1 pitch
120 M3x16
120 M3 nuts
6 M8x100
6 M8x75
6 M8x60
12 M8 nuts
6 Nema17 steppers
etc. The frame can be used for a 3DOF bot all the way up to a 6DOF bot. You could even do 2 independent 3DOF heads in the same space with this construction method. You can see that you can mount a stepper in any orientation at any corner. The plastic pieces have rod seats built in so you can mount rods above any of the blue boards. There are also spots to mount an idler pulley everywhere you can mount a stepper. I don't have time to build this monster and the electronics aren't really there yet but I would love for anyone else to take the idea and run. This was an idea in my head that I just had to get out or I would go crazy. Now that it is out, I now have 20 more ideas of what I could do with it. Arg!!! BTW, the 3DOF version should be quicker to assemble than anything else out there and should be super cheap. (Not as cheap as Simpson or Wally but as cheap as a bot with rails can be.) Here is a donation link. Thanks for the support.
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_donations&business=nicholas%2eseward%40gmail%2ecom&lc=US&item_name=Nicholas%20Seward&currency_code=USD&bn=PP%2dDonationsBF%3abtn_donateCC_LG%2egif%3aNonHosted

comments.text: I don't know what MarlinKimbra4Due is, but if it's anything like Marlin, you will find Smoothieware about a dozen times easier to develop for. The file organization is light years better, and the coupling is good and loose. You would simply add a new Arm Solution in src/modules/robot/arm_solutions and a section in the config file (human-readable text), and probably a few minor things elsewhere. With Marlin, you will be playing with spaghetti all day.

The original fridge door guidance system, which came with my IKEA refridgerator, broke. Since one cannot buy this thing as a spare part I designed and printed one. The two pieces, "rail" and "cage", form a guidance/slide system for the IKEA fridge door and its front panel door. The rail (fridgeslide.4.stl) is screwed to the inside of the front panel door. The cage (fridgeslide-cage-1.6_konische-Schraubenkoepfe.stl), which will slide on the rail, is screwed to the outside of the fridge door. Opening/closing the front panel door will open/close the fridge door at the same time.
Designed with Designspark Mechanical and printed with PLA filament on a GermanRepRap Neo 3Dprinter.

description.text:
This is my version of ZMR250  RcExplorer look , David designed a nice tricopter, I don`t like tricopters , so I build somethink that look similar to his design.
This version can be so thin because I used a polish board named KFC32FTB which contains  OSD , LongRange link in one pcb plate.
Three parts are milled from FR4 fiberglass , you`ll see from the pictures ( therefore the IGS files ) 
From my experience there are different ZMR250 versions which different in hole positions, the front holes are 30.5mm and some times 32mm , this is the 30.5mm version , if you like the other then ask , I`ll upload modified version.

This is a corner bumper for the Wink Connect 3G 7" Tablet. After my kids broke 3 tablets I decided it was time for some protection. It has not been drop tested so I can't guarantee it works, but it should be better than nothing. UPDATE: It also fits the Alcatel One Touch Pixi 3 (7) and probably other tablets of the same size. The profile fit is not perfect, but good enough. I printed it in nylon as it is durable and impact resistant as well as somewhat flexible and makes mounting easier.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.125

Infill:

30-50%

Notes: The bottom is 1mm thick so I used 4 top and 4 bottom layers to make it solid. You need support in the corners and below the fillet outside, but if your slicer has the option, disable the support in the channels below. It will be hard to remove.

Clean the support and any strings and other defects. The 4 channels in the bottom of the corners are designed to take pieces of 1.75mm NinjaFlex filament or other rubber band of similar size to prevent the tablet from slipping.
Just stretch the rubber to reduce its diameter, stick it in the channel and release it. It will get stuck. Trim from the outside and you are done.

description.text:
This is in progress. It is already online to improve mistakes and optimize.
Some parts are missing, they are coming soon. This is a fully printable table saw, to saw pcb, small wooden, metal pieces or all kind of soft material.
I have serached such a tool on Thingiverse and on the Internet, but I dind't have found any matchable tool which is so cheap and easy to make.
So I decided to make one and this is the prototype. I also added the CAD-files, so you can customize, optimize and modify the part, but let me know your modifications. At the moment you don't can adjust the cutting depth. You could only adjust it with the diameter of the cuting blade, with a 40mm blade you have a depth of 2mm. I have buy these for prototying (http://www.banggood.com/10pcs-40mm-Diamond-Grinding-Wheel-Cutting-Disc-with-2-Mandrels-for-Dremel-Rotary-Tool-p-987968.html). It is not perfect, but with cost of 10 - 20$ without the dremel it does the job pretty well. Please leave comments to improve this thing. For the assembly instructions scroll down.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Layerheight: 0.3mm

Infill:

20% or 100% I made mine with 20%

Notes: I printed of black PLA with a diameter of 1.75mm.
Supports are recommanded, not at all parts but I used it on the baseplate and on the dust collector.
With my settings the printing time was about 14h.

Printed Parts: 1x Baseplate
4x Legs
1x Dremel mount
1x Coverage of your choice (optionally)
1x Dust collector (optionally)
1x Stop angle (optionally) Other Parts: 1x Dremel (I used Dremel 4000)
1x Saw blade (min. Ø 40mm for a cutting depth 2mm)
16x Countersunk head screw Ø2,5 x 12mm (Woodscrew)
1x Screw M4
1x Washer M4
1x Nut M4

STEP 1: Take the baseplate, the four legs and eight screws and screw the legs to each corner. STEP 2: Take the dremel mount and four screws and screw it to the baseplate. STEP 3: Add the M4 screw, washer and nut to the stop angle, the screwhead is under the angle then cames the angle and on the top the washer and the nut. Now you can slide the screw with the angle in the long hole. STEP 4: Add the other parts and the dremel. Now you can add the saw blade and the saw blade holder. STEP 5: Take the dust collector and screw it to the four holes around the saw blade cut.

This is a 3D scan of the "Mater Matuta". The statue is on the "Museo Provinciale Campano" site in Capua.
The Provincial Museum Campano (also known as the Museum of Campania) is a historical museum of ancient Campania (later Terra di Lavoro and now included in the Province of Caserta), and one of the most important of the Campania and Italy. It holds the most important collection of world Matres Matutae, also known as the Mothers of Capua, from the ancient Capua, the present territory of the City of Santa Maria Capua Vetere and the largest lapidarium (collection of inscriptions, steles and tombstones of stone age substantially Roman) in southern Italy.
Mater Matuta, in Roman mythology was the goddess of the Morning or Dawn and then patron of the birth of men and things. He was later associated with the Greek goddess Ino or, in fact, Aurora. This is the wikipedia font for the Museum and Mater Matuta:(https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museo_provinciale_campano_di_Capua)

description.text:
Yes, yet another spool holder.
I wanted something to support the larger 5lb spools along with the 2.2lb spools.
I needed to be able to load the spool from the front of the table due to the way I have the machines laid out.
I have lots of leftover 8mm rods that are not suitable for precision use so they became the axles. You will need four skate bearings (had a bunch of those leftover).
I suspect this would work just fine with wooden dowel and printed bushing to hold them.
Oh, the cross member is 1/2" PVC irrigation pipe. yep I have a lot of that laying around too.

author: stemclubuk

description.text:
Our automated fish food feeder tended to spill the food outside the tank because it's a cheap 10 gallon tank and the feeding hole in the lid is relatively small and/or not designed for the feeder we're using. For a while we had a piece of plastic in there, but my wife had the idea to 3D print a funnel! After a couple of iterations, we arrived on this design. I printed the main part of the funnel at 100% infill, and the block that attaches to it at 10% infill to save on material. I sliced the model in half in netfabb free to permit easier completion of the above two-part print. Designed to fit the feeding hole of the below aquarium hood:
http://www.petsmart.com/fish/lighting-hoods/all-glass-aquarium-incandescent-hood-zid36-5063883/cat-36-catid-300015 The feeder we have is this one:
http://www.petsmart.com/food-care/automatic-feeders/national-geographic-trade-aqua-auto-fish-feeder-zid36-5230306/cat-36-catid-300037

author: Philswift1950

description.text:
A full set of looms, 4 circular loom sizes (XS-S-M-L, approx. 6cm-12cm-19cm-27cm internal diameter) + a customizable set for rectangular loom Full size looms are available for download but only XS (maybe S, too) can be printed in once, that's why each of them is divided into pieces:
S and M circular looms and rectangular loom are divided into 4 pieces, L loom into 6 Just print the basic shape four times or add the final part with the horizontal peg to "lock" the yarn, useful but not essential
The pegs are designed to insert a 4mm size crochet and easily get the yarn loop Each piece has 3 holes with 2mm diameter. you can use leftovers filament to join the pieces, a little glue will help keeping it all together and avoid disassembling while using it INSTRUCTIONS
each file is named like this:
loom_sizeXnumberofprints.stl so if you see the file named
loom_LX1
it's the L size loom and this file must be printed once
again, loom_SX3
it's the S size loom and this file must be printed three times for the rectangular loom (named scarf loom) the file name is
LOOM_scarf
BIG is the 6pegs piece and is supposed to be printed in pair
LTL is the 3pegs piece and is supposed to be printed in pair
U is the U shaped piece (short side of the loom) and, guess what? it is supposed to be printed in pair, too! =D

title: Headphone Hook improved for different shelf thickness
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is an improvement/remix of the one made by "Misguided" on Feb 9, 2011.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6256 The original design allows to hang the headphones under your office desktop. This new remix is based on the version 4 of his short and large hooks models, that have the bracket bend inwards slightly to reduce some of the sagging of the bracket under load. This new remix includes the following improvements:
  • The lower lateral arch has increased its height to provide more protection to the headphones because with the original design I noticed that the headphones used to fall down if a near chair hit accidentaly to them. With this new protection the probability of falling down has been reduced.
  • The large and short hooks now have the same thickness in the sides of the bracket bend. They have been equalized to give more sturdiness to the whole structure.
  • The lower corner of the bracket bend has reduced its radius. Now it is equal to the upper corner. It should help to avoid the bending due to the weight of the headphone.
  • The STL files generated have reduced the size. Now they have 130 Kbytes approx.
    • To give more opportunities to the Thingiverse users of using this remix, different models has been designed for different thickness of shelves / desktops. There are 4 files for each thickness:
  • xx.yy_large_high_headphone_hook_sxs.stl (large hook with lower lateral arch increased)
  • xx.yy_large_normal_headphone_hook_sxs.stl (large hook with original lateral arch)
  • xx.yy_short_high_headphone_hook_sxs.stl (short hook with lower lateral arch increased)
  • xx.yy_short_normal_headphone_hook_sxs.stl (short hook with original lateral arch)
    • The different thickness included are: 10.00 mm 15.00 mm 15.30 mm 19.00 mm 20.00 mm 21.00 mm 22.50 mm 23.20 mm 24.00 mm 25.00 mm 26.00 mm 30.00 mm 35.00 mm 40.00 mm 45.00 mm 50.00 mm The thing files list has been ordered by the thickness value to facilitate the search. Please note that only the ones that have the 25.00 mm thickness have been printed/tested succesfully with the desktop I own which is 25 mm thick. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you find any error or you need another thickness not included. Although the ones included should be the most common I would do the best to generate the new thing file with the thickness you need in case of none of the rest helps you. As Misguided said with his original design, it is recommended using a little bit of double-sided tape (or any temporary adhesive that won't damage the shelf) to attach the hook to the shelf. Finally I want to give thanks to Misguided for his original design and I hope my work helps as well.

Although I selected 0.8 mm for shell thickness and it worked fine for me, it would be useful to test with a lower value in case one piece does not fit well on the desk. As Misguided said with his original design, it is recommended using a little bit of double-sided tape (or any temporary adhesive that won't damage the shelf) to attach the hook to the shelf.
The "Brim" platform adhesion type selected in Cura slicer can be removed easily with a cutter.

author: uejini

description.text: Based on the world war 2 Lancaster bomber

Got fed up with builds for filaments spools. So, made my version. It's a "one fits all" whatever your configuration, this one will be usable. It's simple to make; adaptable to any filament spool size; uses bearings for smooth rolling. Parts needed: aluminium 8mm rod (cheap, easy to cut); Rope + 4x 3mm screws (or you could use 3DP filament, slide it in the slots and heat+press the ends); electric tape (it stretches + the glue lasts a long time); and 4x 608ZZ bearings The rope goes in the slot between the elements to prevent them from sliding apart. Bonus: anything that stops the entire build from sliding (when you arrive at the end of the roll; you'll need more friction) : soft PVC sheet; rubber band (these tend to dry and break with time); caouchouc (rubber from and old bike tire); etc. Notes:

  • put the tape on the rods after inserting the bearings. Stretch while applying the tape, and make more than one turn so that the tape grips on itself. The purpose of the tape is to prevent the rod from sliding out of position by adding just enough diameter so that it exceeds the diameter of the bearing. Works great on a smooth rod or tube of exact 8mm size. not sure if it does on a threaded rod. aluminium rod makes it easy to work things out.

  • The bearing slot is intentionally made as a tight fit (In the 3D model, the diameter is 22.25mm but with printing variations, you'll probably get a 22mm; if you dont get a tight fit, reduce the scale of the model to 95%). To insert the bearing, gently hammer the bearing in the slot. Gently = rubber hammer; or use a soft and flat material to buffer the impacts, a piece of wood for example)

author: jerryciano

title: Animal and Plant Cell Construction Kit

description.text: Make a model of an animal or plant cell. Making models of animal and plant cells is a common middle school science activity. Now you can 3D print your cell model. Customize or remix as you please, put a hole in it and make a keychain, whatever you like. Open the file Animal and Plant cell Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com and you'll have all the parts you need. Or download the parts individually and put them together in your favorite cad program. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Pc42eJLU5Y

The easiest way for students to build their cells is to search for and open the file Animal and Plant Cell Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Pc42eJLU5Y. All the parts are in that file and students just need to move them into the correct position and then delete the extra pieces to have a printable model. Students will want to use the arrow keys to help them move parts into the correct position. They will not need to resize the pieces or lift them off the workplane. They can copy or duplicate to make extra copies of the organelles, and they can be rotated to add some variety to the lay out.
NGSS

Make a model of an animal or plant cell. Making models of animal and plant cells is a common middle school science activity. Now you can 3D print your cell model. Customize or remix as you please, put a hole in it and make a keychain, whatever you like. Open the file Animal and Plant cell Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com and you'll have all the parts you need. Or download the parts individually and put them together in your favorite cad program. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Pc42eJLU5Y

• Go to Tinkercad.com and find the Animal and Plant Cell Construction Kit file and open it https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Pc42eJLU5Y
  • Choose either the animal cell or plant cell. Lock it in place and delete the one you don't want
  • Drag and drop the organelles into position in the cytoplasm
  • Use Copy or Duplicate to make extra copies of organelles
  • You can use rotate to reposition the organelles
  • Delete all the extra pieces and labels
  • Print your cell model
  • Optional: You can use paint or markers to color the organelles

Objective Students will design and print a 3D model of an animal or plant cell, or both. Audience This project is intended for an 8th grade class but could be used for grades 6 - 8. Preparation Students should have a basic understanding of the cell, it's parts and their functions. The 3D design process using Tinkercad is relatively easy and would be a good project for beginners. Steps
  • Go to Tinkercad.com and find the Animal and Plant Cell Construction Kit file and open it https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4Pc42eJLU5Y
  • Choose either the animal cell or plant cell. Lock it in place and delete the one you don't want
  • Drag and drop the organelles into position in the cytoplasm
  • Use Copy or Duplicate to make extra copies of organelles
  • You can use rotate to reposition the organelles
  • Delete all the extra pieces and labels
  • Print your cell model
  • Optional: You can use paint or markers to color the organelles
    • Results This project was completed as described with two 8th grade classes. The students were able to create both an animal cell and plant cell during one 45 minute class period. A few students accidentally shifted pieces above or below the workplane, so make sure they check for that before attempting to print modelsl

author: Toddwats001

title: Annular Cooling for Ultimaker V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement annular cooling for the Ultimaker nozzle. The original cooling shroud, although functional, can sometimes be counterproductive. The unidirectional nature of the cooling stream can sometimes lift the first layer, especially when printing on a raft. The annular cooling nozzle is aimed at the printed object from all directions, thus cancelling any possible lift.  
This version 2 of my previous design. It has a larger annulus to prevent it from melting, more airflow and simpler geometry. This version has only two parts to print and glue with superglue.

Print both parts with flat faces on the platform. I used 0.1mm layer thickness and 100% fill for strength. You will also need the following:
2x M3x20mm bolts
2x M3 nuts
2x M3 PCB spacer File bolt holes using a needle-file to allow M3 bolts to pass through comfortably. Align through the bolt holes using bolts and glue the two parts using super glue. The use of super glue accelerator is advised. Slide assembly in place under the cooling fan through the innermost prodruding long screws.
Retighten the long screws before securing the assembly in place using 2xM3 PCB spacers. One of the bolt holes is too deep to get the PCB spacer to even get a grip on the long screw. Use a M3 bolt to joint the two PCB spacer and tighten, then use this ellongated spaced to secure the cooling assembly in place. Use a mini-wrench an an allen key to untighten the lower PCB spacer from the top then remove it. The second hole is not that deep, so the secon PCB spacer should have enough grip to tighten using amin-wrench. Secure the rest of the assembly to the fan using 2x M3x20mm bolts and nuts. STEP files included. Enjoy! If you like this design, feel free to donate and ask for improvements:
https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=AW57FTXN35YZE

Making crepes, especially spreading the paste, needs some training. This little thing might help you - watch the video: https://youtu.be/gG-FRvKEr7M crepes1.stl is clipped onto part crepes2.stl, this connection works as a hinge.

Using the star pattern from my Islamic Design Clothes Hanger (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1239548) I made a coaster for tea mugs.

comments.text: I have seen this so many times with "coaster" projects here, but do you know what a coaster is?  What the purpose they server?  Based on some of these designs, you don't.  A drink coaster is to protect the surface the glass is set on from the condensation that can form on the outside and drip to the bottom.  The coaster is suppose to contain that water so it doesn't get on surface of the furniture, or whatever it is the drink is on you are trying to protect.  Making a coaster with holes kind of defeats the purpose of a coaster.
comments.author: halsare

comments.text: thanks...yes...I was thinking of what to call it because of that "feature." I am personally using it for hot tea on a stone surface I want to protect from the heat of the direct contact of a mug. It works great as a thermal barrier and there is no condensation as you have with a cold glass. Also, if you notice there are small holes in the surface, which whisk away any moisture. So for my use it works great. I guess if you had cold glasses on a wooden surface you would want to use something else.

This case holds a Raspberry pi B+ or B 2 and a USB-Soundcard (in my case a Createive SoundBlaster Play) and a two-Port 12V-to-USB vehicle adapter.
It is designed that one USB-Port of the adapter is dissolderd, the other has an outside-connection for powering other things (like a 4G router).
The housing has also a hole for the LAN-Port an a 15-pin d-sub connector. In my case, there is also a CAN-bus-controller installed.
The power, CAN and audio signals are all connected via the d-sub connector.

This thing turns my Barda Jarrex lightsaber into a display piece into one that lights up. Basically we're adding a flashlight here. The lightsaber is designed to fit a flashlight inside. I use one of the super cheap Nine LED Flashlights from Harbor Freight (http://www.harborfreight.com/3-12-in-9-led-mini-flashlight-69111.html) that they'll usually give you for free with purchase. To add this thing to the existing Barda Jarrex Lightsaber you'll need to drill a hole in the pommel of the lightsaber for the top of the push stick to protrude. The flashlight will need to be installed in the grip facing forward towards the emitter. Tear off the rubber button cover of the flashlight so the Push Tube Bottom will fit tight against the back of the flashlight. Stick all of the pieces together and you've got yourself a working lightsaber/flashlight thing.

Printer:

3dFreaks

Rafts:

No

Supports:

description.text: This is a custom bracket used to mount an iPhone 4 to a 60Beat Controller for control of an AR.Drone quad-copter. This version allows the use of the iPhone while still in a case. The iPhone is off center so that the display is centered for viewing when flying in FPV mode. The unit is presently somewhat top heavy, and so I may add either handle extensions or handle counterweights to balance it out in a future version. You may want to redesign the iPhone shell to better fit your cased iPhone, or create a custom spacer to use with the provided shell.

• Use a 5mm tap to thread the top portion of the center three holes on the back of the 60Beat as shown in the photo.
  • Glue the connecting bracket to the smooth side of the back plate for best adhesion. Check the photos for orientation before gluing.
  • Glue the iPhone shell to the connecting bracket with the cutout for the earphone jack at the upper right corner.
  • Mount the assembled iPhone mount onto the back of the controller using three M5 x 7mm button head screws. Only thread the screws in far enough to press lightly on the back plate, as the plate is flat and the controller surface is irregular.

comments.text: Nice! How do you connect the controller with the iphone to control the ar.drone? And does it work with the first version of the drone?
comments.author: lukasbieri

comments.text: The controller uses the earphone jack to communicate with the iPhone app. The app is 'Drone Control US', and can be purchased through iTunes. The app can be used without the 60Beat also. No batteries required.

This is my rendition of a laser cut leather wallet.
I found it difficult to find the exact design I wanted, so I made this one. Be sure to scale the svg correctly before printing.
If you wish to raster in an emblem, it goes on the bottom left panel (the 45 degree cuts are sewn onto the "bottom" of the wallet).
The card window in the top right should be the size of the cards you wish to put into the wallet (as some software doesn't import it correctly - I'm looking at you, adobe illustrator).

Cutter Settings and Materials I used an epilog mini laser (12x24 30W) to cut this out.
Settings for my leather were picked out by printing a grid of settings then picking the ones that appeared to work best.
To do it all in one pass, I edited the stroke width to be vector cuts (0.001" stroke) and added fills for the images I wanted rastered. The leather i used is about 0.05" (1.2mm). Don't use any thicker leather, as you may not have enough space to sew the layered seams.
Clear panel for drivers license used random clear durable plastic that I had lying around.
Thread used is thick nylon thread.

title: Lamp bulb holder E27 - High voltage

description.text: This is a dangerous build due to the high voltage involved. You have to know the dangers and potential issues: Short-circuits and loose wires. This build probably violates any good electrician guidelines. A lamp or bulb holder designed for the iDual LED bulb by Müller Licht or Jedi Lighting (http://www.mueller-licht.de/produktinformationen/artikel/400009/). But should fit any LED bulb. It can stand on a table or be mounted on a wall by a screw/nail. It is meant to provide electricity for the bulb by electrical contacting. Only for LED bulbs! No tungsten bulbs, these will melt the mount immediately. The cooling fins of the LED I use reach up to 70°C. But the screw base of the bulb is only below 30°C. The mount does not deform or melt. You will need two 10mm M3 screws and four M3 nuts, two paper-clips for inner contacting, a cable tie and a wire with a plug. As always a STEP file is included for easy changes and adjustments.

The required steps in the following are documented as photos also.
  • First you have to bend the paper-clips with pliers to create a nice contact spring. Then screw in the clips with the screws and fasten them with nuts from the back. You can check the contacting with a regular screwed-in tungsten bulb and a multimeter. You can correct the contact clips if necessary.
  • Now take the cable and solder the ends to prevent single strings from going off potentially causing a short-circuit later. Bend the wires like a hook and fasten them with another M3 nut tightly. Be careful to not to create a short circuit. The gab is very small.
  • Use a cable tie to prevent the cable from being ripped out. You can also fixate the cable by glue.
  • Clean up the hooks from the back plate with a knife so they fit the grooves in the main body nicely. They are usually molten from printing.

title: Cylon Raider - Battlestar Galactica by Neophyte Remix 300%

description.text:
This is a remix in progress.
I cut the front part of the model into 2 separate stl files. I scaled the bottom section of the front part by 300%. I then printed it using Simplify 3D to slice using 3 processes which I included here. I will upload the other parts as soon as I print them. I am very happy with the detail. There was only filing and knifing done so far. The process settings are for Wanhao i3, but if you view the settings you can still use the layer and fill info as well as the feed rates. The first print took almost 9 hours.
I used the cheap Inland Silver PLA filament from Microcenter. I get pretty good results with most Inland filament, but I do get more clogs than with Hatchbox or better. Inland filament seems a bit dry and more brittle, but you can't beat the price.
This is still a remix in progress. I don't like the thin front fin orientation. It makes for too weak a part. I am trying out laying them flat on the table. Simplify 3D has a place surface on bed command.

author: cudbur

description.text:
This is my version bowden x carriage and j-head mount for prusa mendel.
I based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45883 (thank you for openscad file I reused).
My main plan was to create 2 X-carriage prusa mendel main changes:
  • allows symmetrical both side 2 X-carriage belts (see part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128514)
  • moved hotend 3.5cm higher
    v6:
  • easier mount of bowden tube
    • Update (10/19/2013) from v6
  • issues with wobble and not tight grip on linear bearings forced me to create clamps to hold tight to bearing
    -cutout for hotend cables.
    • Update (8/06/2013) - printed parts and assembly - pictures Update (8/05/2013) from v5:
  • separated bowden tube mount and j-head mount from carriage
    • Update (7/30/2013) from v3:
  • moved up by another 1.5cm
  • slim down design, better positioning of belt clamps, added one belt clamp
  • fans mount straight

Instructions:
  • print parts with support and clean up.
  • put carriage on 2 linear bearings and clamp them with screws
  • drill bowden tube size hole in top plate - bowden tube I used was 3/16 in OD and 1/8 in ID - you can modify the size in parameters on beginning of scad file.
  • put bowden tube through hole and screw on the M5 nut, bowden tube was little squeezed and couldn't pass 3mm filament easly - I used 1/8 in drill to adjust that.
  • assemble part with 4x M3-25mm screws with washers/nuts on bottom. 2 side plates slides into hotend holder. Slide M3 nuts into bottom plate mounts, they should attach quite well, so it will be easier to screw in.
  • mount carriage parts to bearings
  • mount 40mm fans onside
  • mount bowden + j-head mount to carriage with 4 nuts slided into holes in carriage and M3-25mm screws
  • attach belt clamp - I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31482, need little work around with ziplocks becasue my belt wasn't that bold.
  • extruder mount is from thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25683
  • calibrate bed (z axis)
    • Improvements of v7?
  • move belt on side bottom? (idea from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22887)

title: High Light Bulb Changer for Paint Pole

description.text:
This is a high light bulb changer. I'm was surprised to find none were on here.
This is for, you know, those super annoyingly high light bulbs that are over a stairway or some other awkward place. The bulbs you can't get to without doing some sketchy ladder work, yeah, those ones. This 3D printable adapter screws onto a paint (or shop broom) pole and (with the help of a soda bottle) allows you to change the light bulb from safely standing on the floor.
First, print the adapter with the large diameter (threaded side) down on the print bed. I used PLA with 0.3mm layers on a MakerGear M2 using Cura without support but using a brim. All part features printed great. No complaints. 
There are two diameter sizes to fit different soda/water bottles. Glue the adapter into a bottle opening. Trim the bottle as shown in the photos. The conical section of the bottle is great for gripping the pesky bulb. Screw the adapter to a paint pole and you're in business.
I was able to unscrew a bulb with only the bottle plastic touching the bulb but it was a bit finicky. I cut some anti-slip cabinet liner material to fit inside the bottle and it was a 1000% improvement in the bulb changing experience.

author: Zalophus

title: LulzBot IP Mini Logitech C270 IP Cam & LED Mount

description.text:
Needed a mount for my Logitech C270 and LEDs for monitoring / recording prints using OctoPrint. Note, this requires a mount for the C270 (or your IP cam) as well as an interface to the mounting arm. I used flex arm parts and did some custom work. Links to those parts:
C270 Mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1066718
Flex Hose: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1014657 Steps:
  • Print all the parts included here, the camera mount and a flex hose.
  • For the camera mount, you can use the tube and screws that come from dismantling the exiting C270 mount. Put those together.
  • You will have to cut down (dremel or hacksaw) the flex hose piece. It needs to be glued inside the upper part of the camera mount arm (the piece that has the curve). My cut was about half. You will also want to take a knife and scrape the rim of the arm so that there is more area for the glue to bond to.
  • Once the mount arm and flex tube glue has dried, you need to insert the ball end of the flex tube piece (mounted to the camera) into the receiving end of the flex tube you cut down earlier. Note - I did this using PLA as it has a low melting temperature. You will need to use some other method if you are using PLA or other materials.
    • Here's the trick I figured out. Boil some water, and put it in a tray or cup. Hold the end of the flex tube part about 5 mm into the water for 5 seconds. Then quickly pop it into the socket. Do not move it and keep it straight. You can hold your fingers around the end to ensure the socket ends are tight. http://www.plastibots.com/index.php/2016/01/03/lulzbot-ip-mini-cam-led-mount/ This and other cool stuff at http://www.plastibots.com

I made this very simple model to use it as an inlay for the front-center armrest of my new Audi A5 Sportback (B8). If gives you a flat area to put larger smartphones on it, which do not fit in otherwise. Additionally you can hide your charging cables or any audio cables underneath it. 
My build fits perfectly in the space in the car. After glueing 1 mm thick felt on top and to the sides, it sits very tight and its hard to recognize that its a self-built thing. To remove it or access the space underneath, I pull the cable which is fittet through the aperture (see pictures).

title: X-Labs Shrike GoPro Mounts (replaces Top Plate)

description.text:
This replaces the entire top-plate for the X-Labs.us Shrike frame. I wanted something that could fit a recording camera on, and with no solution out there already I took to learning how to do it myself. Currently has the following features:
  • SMA VTX Mount (may need adjustments to finetune location)
  • 35 degree GoPro / Xiaomi Yi Mount
  • Holes for Cable ties to attach RX antennas.
  • Multiple HS1177 Mounting options (M3 or 2x M2).
    • Overall I'm pleased with it. I will fly it and adjust accordingly, so please treat this as work in progress NEW 26/02/2016: Added a V4.5 under the files section - has only the 2 outer screws for the HS1177 to help with bridging and keep strength, tolerances increased and I would call this a final version. It differs to V3 because you can fit a full-size battery strap IN the mount, to stop any pains of feeding between the camera and it's mounting plate. It is slightly heavier due to needing to be taller, but works well. This version does require support, but only a small amount. NEW 28/02/2016: Added a V4.6.1 - This is a 40 degree mount, with a complete redesign of the top section; more rear support and gopro moved forwards to stop fouling the antenna. rear sma-mount made thicker towards the top section - this should stop any breakages at the rear. NOTE: I also run a Cable-tie around my antenna and gopro strap this means all force is removed from the SMA completely now :)

description.text:
The throttle is broken on my outboard engine, and I wonder if maybe I could print a new one. I've made a sketch of what it might look like, but it's really a work in progress so far. I need a mechanism that restricts the movement in a good way, so that it stays in a single position when untouched, but can be moved simply by forcing it. I guess a button could be used, but seems complicated. Maybe I could use a spring and some component that pushes against something else. Not sure what a good way of doing it is. 
The plan is to have a wire from the motor (similar to a brake/gear wire on a bike) going into the side of the box and fastening the wire to the top screw (grey pin in the diagram). The bottom grey pin is meant to hold the handle to the box and allow it to rotate. 
I've added a picture of the current design. This one doesn't have the files yet, but I'll post later. If someone want them now, let me know.
It's work in progress. Have posted here to see if someone has feedback.

title: PrintRite DIY 3D Printer Fan Duct v3

description.text:
My 3rd (and continually evolving) design for a fan duct for the PrintRite DIY 3D Printer. Includes adapters for either a 40mm fan or a 50x15mm blower. This design fits completely within the outline of the extruder carriage and extends below the carriage via the opening between the metal cross-bar and the front plastic piece to the left of the extruder fan/heatsink. It also does not badly obscure the view of the extruder nozzle. Included are 8 STL files:
  • Lower Duct
  • Scalable Shim
  • 50x15 Blower Adapter
  • 40mm Fan Adapter
  • 2nd Lower Duct option with internal supports for shorter bridging during printing
  • Flat 40mm Fan Adapter that does not have any overhangs to make it easier to print
  • Flat 40mm Fan Adapter that has internal air channeling structures for (maybe) better airflow
  • New Mk. II version of the Lower Nozzle that directs the air downward more to avoid cooling the print head and to provide more clearance above the print bed. (Added 12/14/2016)
    • You'll need 2 M3 screws about 12mm long, plus appropriate screws to mount the fan of your choice to the adapter block of your choice. If printing the 40mm adapter with the internal air director, print it upside-down and drill out the main screw holes - it has to have a thin closed-off bridged over area in these screw holes to print upside down correctly. Let me know if you want me to design adapters for additional fan types, or feel free to do so yourself. I have uploaded a PDF with the dimensions of the top plate of the lower nozzle so you can easily design your own fan adapter.

Print the lower nozzle first and determine how much shim spacing will be required above the metal crossbar to get the bottom of the nozzle 1-2 mm above the print bed. Change the scaling on the Z-dimension of the shim to set the height. I needed 6mm. The STL file is 10mm high, so I scaled the Z to 60%.
You may need to rotate the heater block around and change which end of the heater block the heater catridge is inserted in. ( Loosen the small set screws to rotate the block and remove the cartridge)   I have my heater cartridge with the leads coming out of the left rear of the heater block.
You will need to remove the 2 M3 allen screws holding the cross bar down to get the duct in place.  Replace the bar, install the shim under the duct's flange, and put the fan adapter on top, then add the M3 screws through all 3 pieces into the holes in the top of the metal cross-bar.
If you plan on using a 40mm fan, remove the existing extruder fan and move it to the fan adapter.  Mount the fan to the duct with some sheet metal screws. Install a new 40mm fan on the Extruder. Run a new pair of wires to supply constant 12V power to the new fan on the extruder. I'm pretty sure the Extruder fan should be running all the time to maintain the correct temperature gradient inside the nozzle, not varied as it is from the factory. I also used this 12V constant power to run a section of LED strip under the carriage. It gets dark under there..
If using a 50x15 blower, leave the 40mm extruder fan on the extruder, but cut the wires and connect the new blower to the wires that the extruder fan was powered by.  Run new 12v constant power to the extruder fan.
I highly recommend insulating the heater block a bit so the printer can maintain extruder temperatures while the fan is running.  I wrapped mine in several layers of Kapton-style tape, leaving only the print nozzle sticking out.  With the Mk II fan nozzle and the tape, my printer is now able to maintain the head temp within a few degrees of target temperature even with the rather powerful 50x15mm blower at 100% speed.  Without the tape and with the 1st nozzle design, the heater was unable to maintain the head temp at high fan speeds.

description.header: Important Info for full fan speeds!
description.text: I noticed that my blower did not run at full speed when the fan output was set to 100%. I discovered the problem in a design flaw in the control board. There is a 10k resistor in between the Atmega1284p chip and the NPN transistor that runs the fan, which is too high of a resistance to fully turn on the transistor. I bodged in a 1K ohm resistor between the Atmega1284p and the base leg of the transistor and voila! Full speed! The resistor is connected across R47, the incorrect value 10K ohm resistor. I take no responsibility for you blowing up your own boards, so proceed at your own risk if you want to make the same modifications.

comments.text: PLA is fine if you aren't planning on doing a lot of long prints with higher temperature plastics like ABS.  If you're planning on printing in PLA mostly you'll be fine with PLA.   My PLA lower duct started sagging a bit after several long duration ABS prints.  It was still usable but not as nice looking.  I've since switched to ABS for the lower duct.   Great thing about having a 3D printer is that if it melts, you can always make another one!
comments.author: dcclark

comments.text: So, i will need the lower part, and after that, how to measure the correct distance for the shim? Disassemble?
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: Yes, I realize it's a little bit of a pain but you should only have to remove the two Allen head cap screws on the bottom that hold the bar down and lift the bar up a bit to get the nozzle to fit in.   You could also print a small assortment of the shim pieces - maybe a 2mm, a 4mm, and a 6mm and see which one fits best on the first and hopefully only disassembly.
comments.author: dcclark

comments.text:
That's a cool idea, I will print a bunch and only disassemble once. I want to use the stock 40mm fan, so after the lower part will I only need one part more printed, right?
Oh, I see in this moment, I must also re-route the thermistor cable and the heater?
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: Yeah.  One fan adapter, one lower duct, one shim will be the three parts you'll use.
comments.author: dcclark

comments.text:
Hi Owl!
i just did my first test of bridges with your new fan duct ; and i have to say that it seems to be a major upgrade!
thank you for sharing that!!!
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text: Very nice.  Glad you like it!
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
Hi Mr Owl, strange thing, I have made your fan shroud up as you know, but when I run a print the temperature is exactly the same as it was, and I mean within one degree. If I used to run at 210 degrees then the new setup runs between 209 and 210 for the extruder, if I set the hot bed to 60 the temp is held between 59 and 60 degrees. It's rock solid, I also only needed a 3mm spacer for my installation, strange that there should be such a change in dimension from one machine to the other and I still have about 2 and a half millimetres of clearance above the bed. No Kapton required.
Anyhoo the shroud is working really well, thanks for a good job :)
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: Glad to hear!  I think I may know what would account for the height difference -- I'm running a non-original extruder nozzle that's a few mm shorter than the original one, which would make mine need a bit more spacer.
comments.author: hughee

comments.text: I used the 40mm_Fan_Adapter_With_No_Overhangs.stl, and the Extruder_Fan_Nozzle_Mk_II.stl mate. I have still to do the resistor change to power the 2 fans, but I just watch till the first layer prints and if needed I give one of the fans (if it fails to start) a little spin by hand. Sometimes it starts no problem other times one of them fails, I think your suggestion about the resistir will do the trick, thanks again.
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: very good find with the resistor, noticed the slow fan as well.
comments.author: jandetlefsen

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: brkdwn

comments.text: Yes, supports tend to be hard to remove.  I try to avoid supports if at all possible because I tend to break the piece while trying to remove them.  I used slic3r without supports with no issues. You do need to have the settings fine tuned to support bridging for it to work well.    I may be able to suggest changes that could help improve the results if you can describe or send photos of the failure.   What version of Repetier-host and Slic3r are you using?
comments.author: brkdwn

comments.text:
Hi thank you very much for your help.
i'm using slic3r 1.2.9 and repetier host 1.6.0
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: I've posted 2 new STL files for modifications that may help you get a better print.  Let me know if they help or not.
comments.author: brkdwn

comments.text: Ah yes, in my experience, ABS can definitely have issues with bridging and overhangs.  I have good luck with PLA for parts like this. It warps and distorts much less than with ABS.
comments.author: brkdwn

comments.text: Where do you get the extra 12v from? Is there a header on the control board?
comments.author: sidneylopsides

comments.text: I ran a new pair of wires through the harness to the control board and rather crudely connected the new wires to the solder joints on the main power input connector.  It's not pretty, but it works and is hidden under the control board cover.  I think that there is at least one empty plug/header on the board that delivers 12v, but as I didn't spend a lot of time on it and didn't have the correct connector for it, I didn't try any of them.
comments.author: sidneylopsides

comments.text: Very Nice !!

comments.text: Thanks!

To use the water tube, fill with water and then lower the vase over it... add flower :-) With some flowers the vase is a bit top heavy. I've included a 3D printed mold pattern for sand casting a lead weight to fir in the bottom of the water tube.
FINISHING Remove any stringing with a hot air gun and clean up and rough areas with a file. The water tube will require sealing with PVA or epoxy.
Designed in SolidWorks 2014

title: MK5/MK6 filament plunger screw guide (anti vibration)

description.text: If you still don't have a MK7 extruder (and lots of 3 mm plastic haha... :( ) for sure you experienced this problem with the pluger screw in your MK5/6: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tflRlH45SOk (before) And this is the improved MK5/6: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MKfpU7ZJyJo (after) Then, few prints and your perfect presure over the filament gets modified by this vibration. This guide removes all the problem.

• Print (I used 0.4 mm nozzle, 0.3 mm layer, 60% fill)
  • Screw the original screw, the hole is tight so I used a bit of 3-in-1 oil to make the screw thread
  • Insert the piece and screw into near the original nut (keep the nut near this guide)
  • Adjust the filament pressure now, it will be rock solid :)
  • Enjoy!

remixed_from.title: Scalar Upgrade - Idler holder for GT2 16teeth, 3mm bore Aluminum Idler

title: Scalar Upgrade - Idler fork for Metal Idler 16Teeth GT2 + 625ZZ bearing guides

description.text:
This part is an extended version of the Idler Holder holder for aluminum GT2 16 teeth idler. It can hold an additional 2x625ZZ bearings that you keep in place using either a M5x20 or a M5 threaded rod that you cut at about 20mm long with 2xM5 nuts. The bearings are really interesting in order to keep the belt parallel as much as possible.
On Scalar XL the X carriage is made so that the belt will be trapezoidal instead of parallel to itself. This can impact the precision of the machine.
It has no meaning to use this part however for the X axis. This part is greatly improving this aspect keeping the belt parallel to itself. Print this part 100% infill. 3D Modular Systems

In total 37 *.STL files are required to perform this task and it is intended to be a group project. Collaborative efforts encourage learning from each other’s talents, that being said one person can create this project on their own.
Scaling at a uniform scale or sectioning the model may improve the outcome if the printer used is not large enough to make the model components in one piece.
To summarize this project is about gothic creationism. To build out and up, this is the basic premise of 3d modeling. The chess pcs have base guides with arrows describing the direction of each player’s capabilities making the learning curve much easier. Just like Microsoft made icons say a thousand words, these guides will stop the novice questioning how each player moves and how they coordinate attacks. The middle pedestal should be made from clear crystal which is easy enough if you make the reverse mould from the models included.
The board is elongated and risen up at each rank, creating a more realistic perspective of the game but changing no other aspect of the games rules. Knights attack and defense patterns are circles of the opposite color from the moves start but in gothic chess the attack profile is an oval that changes depending on the placement of the pc on the board. Similarly the angles of attack from queens and bishops are more curved and less obvious increasing the level of competition.
I used auto cad for the starting models and imported to 3d studio max which I then exported as STL files for printing. I could have used other formats but STL seems to be most often used for printing. I used very simple math to design the board with a logical and even progression to keep the games logic intact. Team work between the player peace’s are what I am expecting from the project participants.
Objectives in this project are scaling or sectioning the model, testing fit between components and adjusting sizes to have a more smooth fit. Using different mediums like making reverse moulds for liquid crystal, leather or cloth for the covering, painting the exterior and blocks of the board as well as taking interest in chess itself as the greatest math teacher in history.
The Audience should be anyone willing to learn chess with icons beneath each piece that teach their moves. The project participants should be intermediate modellers able to address issues that arise from fit of components and testing smaller samples befor making a commitment to a larger project. Any artistic student will see the simplicity of the math creating something new from something old.
In preparation the student s should test themselves and others on Staunton chess sets to investigate how easy or difficult this model is. They should consider the cost of leather for the binding and the crystal for the pedestals of each piece; they should also consider improving the design of the cover or outside or even changes to the step and depth of the design. The size of printers and their precision will be variables that may differ from one class to the next which will change their approach to completing the model and not the least of preparation is the finding of good instructors and equipment.
The most obvious first step would be making the chess pieces in one mould (provided) test the chess pcs on a regular Staunton chess board for sizing and then make the pieces in three steps also included as models of each separate pc. Creating the mid pedestal will require making a reverse mould as each pedestal is unique to the type of pc and base. Making a Boolean subtraction of the words in the base from the mould of the mid-section would make the fit better but the pc themselves may have to be glued or otherwise connected by modeling male and female fixtures.
The board will fold into a book after a cover binding is used, so investing some time into the design and sizing is required. My prototype works well with Velcro for fasteners, but I will not include the size of each cover, that will ensure that the components are not already done and simply put together after printed. (A plastic hinged connection will work just as well as leather)
The playing field sides are identical except for the male and female connections that also could be designed better as incentive for the class to show off their ingenuity. That being said the board is 16” at the longest points which is out of limits for smaller marker bot systems, so the board will have to be made in components (models included) or sectioned or scaled uniformly to complete the project.
I hand painted my prototype which could also be a good part of the project and I also made models of people for the pcs not included. The cooperation of students with different skill sets could produce similar yet different results which are the basics of chess and math.
As result of this project I am hoping the students learn how easy adapting their own creativity to known art work can be a very fulfilling thing to do. Modeling and using different mediums together should teach them how cooperative efforts make the best music. The math I used is simple and repeatable in other projects that they hopefully will have lots of in their future. I have been an architectural draftsman and 3d modeller for over twenty years and find that this is the most rewarding of any work I have ever done. It is true that if you work at what you love you will never really work a day in your life.

Use the pieces to build a model of a molecule. Making models of molecules using ball and sticks or similar materials is a common middle school science activity. Now you can 3D print your molecule model. Open the file Molecule Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com and you'll have all the parts you need. Or download the parts individually and put them together in your favorite cad program. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QKJ0SWFHmN

The easiest way for students to build their molecule is to open the file Molecule Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QKJ0SWFHmN. All the parts are in that file and students just need to move them into the correct position and then delete the extra pieces. Students will want to use the arrow keys to help them move parts into the correct position. They will not need to resize the pieces or lift them off the workplane. They can copy or duplicate to make extra copies of the organelles, and they can use rotate to change the direction of the bonds.

Use the pieces to build a model of a molecule. Making models of molecules using ball and sticks or similar materials is a common middle school science activity. Now you can 3D print your molecule model. Open the file Molecule Construction Kit on Tinkercad.com and you'll have all the parts you need. Or download the parts individually and put them together in your favorite cad program. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QKJ0SWFHmN

• Go to Tinkercad.com and find the Molecule Construction Kit file and open it https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QKJ0SWFHmN
  • Assemble the parts to make your molecule
  • Use Copy or Duplicate to make extra copies of atoms and bonds. You can use rotate to change the angle of the bonds
  • Delete all the extra pieces
  • Print your molecule
    Optional: You can use paint or markers to color the model

Objective Students will design and print a model of a molecule Audience This project is intended for an 7th grade chemistry class but could be used for grades 6 - 8. Preparation Students should have a basic understanding chemical bonds. Students should have a structural diagram of a model to work with so they aren't just putting pieces together in a random way. I included a PDF file with several famous molecules you can download and use. The 3D design process using Tinkercad is relatively easy and would be a good project for beginners. Steps
  • Go to Tinkercad.com and find the Molecule Construction Kit file and open it https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5QKJ0SWFHmN
  • Assemble the parts to make your molecule
  • Use Copy or Duplicate to make extra copies of atoms and bonds. You can use rotate to change the angle of the bonds
  • Delete all the extra pieces
  • Print your molecule
    Optional: You can use paint or markers to color the model
    • Results This project was completed as described with two 7th grade classes. Students were able to complete molecule models in one class period (45 minutes). Two most common problems

  • Leaving small gaps between bonds and atoms so that they are not solidly connected. In Tinkercad the easiest way to check this is to view the model from below the workplane. In this orientation you can clearly see the overlap between the bonds and atoms. It also helps to tell the students that the bonds should go to the middle of the atom, not to the edge.

  • When rotating bonds and stretching them between atoms they will sometimes get too thin. Because Tinkercad's controls move shapes in X, Y, and Z directions it can be hard to widen a bond when it's on an angle. Easiest thing to do in that case is just delete it and duplicate a bond that's the proper thickness and move it into the correct position.

This is an LED rocket design I made as Christmas gifts for family. It has an integrated Arduino driving a couple of LEDs and uses an accelerometer to vary the colors of the lights with the direction of "flight". It also displays a light show when not flown for a few seconds. The rocket comes in top/bottom and an electronics palette with a 9V battery holder. I typically print the palette with supports within the pocket the Arduino slides into. The Arduino source code is available here: https://github.com/erichcr80/Smart-Rocket The original OnShape document is here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/df1463dc8f914260b68c3cf8/w/9c76c30104b34627b618ef78 I can include a pin layout for the Arduino if anyone is interested.

description.text:
I saw a bunch of other drybox filters, but most required hardware or other complicated stuff, so i made this very simple filter, you simply sandwich the box between the 2 pieces and its done, not additional hardware or complicated templates.
Basically you just feed the filament in to the rear printed piece (the flat one), then place your sponge around it and stuff it in as well, then place the piece in to a hole in the box (i used a 3/4" holesaw) and screw the front piece on which secures the whole works... I used a Sterilite 54QT "Gasket Box" which i got from walmart, so it should be pretty accessible to most, and is advertised as being air tight, this may compromise that a bit, but i cant see it being an issue... 
I also used a 1"OD pvc for holding the spools, and included the brackets i made for those, this is going to be pretty specific to my setup, but you never know if someone could use it, so i added it anyway.
There are 1.75 and 3.0mm variations, i intentionally made the holes pretty tight so you can ream out the holes after to get that perfect fit.

title: Customizable Glass Bed Holder (when it is off the printer)

description.text: This is a custom glass bed holder if you have multiple beds and shift them out to let parts cool. You can use it as-is, or grab some Surface Guards from your local hardware store that grab onto glass nicely (pictures have some attached to the 'default' size). We stuck the adhesive pads to the top and bottom of the support cylinders, that is why you see a small gap under the complete piece. It will print with the entire piece flat on your print bed. Be careful about going too big, and make sure it fits on your print bed before starting off. Size it right so it fits your print bed and is a stable base when it is cooling/being stored. The gusseting is strong at 6mm, but can be beefed up if it is required. The one printed is with 2 perimeters and 20% infill, and holds up well. The only thing I would recommend is top and bottom perimeters upped to 3-4 so the adhesives can be pressed into the surface firmly. Each side has a small notch, this is to make it easy to hang out of the way. We hand it on our cork board that holds our order forms, but can be peg or nail mounted. Surface Guard pad example: http://amzn.com/B007ZUENG0

Printer:

Hictop Modified

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm Layer Height

Infill:

20-50%

Notes: Top and bottom perimeters should be set to 3-4, sides can be 2-3. This does not need accuracy, so 0.3mm layer height will get it done faster. Be careful when sizing it, it is a solid one piece print and can really stretch your printer to the maximum bed size.

Surface Guard pads http://amzn.com/B007ZUENG0 These are clear, self stick surface pads designed to grab onto glass and other surfaces. It will ensure a good grip to your glass bed. It is not required, but highly recommended.

title: RC - Herringbone Pinion and Main Spur Gear + Dogbone U-Joint + Rear Differential

description.text:
Project is intending to create a 1/16 or 1/18th scale RC car with cheap electronics (~$200) to include an FPV setup. Parts Used so far:
http://amzn.to/2njenPW <- 15x21x4mm Bearings used in the Differential.
http://amzn.to/2mKWwES <- Carbon Arrows Cheap (~$2.5 per arrow), used for axle shafts Once project is complete, or mostly complete, I will be attempting to get this over to the OpenRC website. This was all done in OpenScad, and the main herringbone gear comes from the openscad library I've linked to as a remix. I created the dogbone universal joints OpenScad without additional libraries, however the idea isn't mine. I simply was trying to find an easy way to create custom length shafts without machining them up. This is definitely a WIP however my friend and myself are taking on the adventure together and wanted to share our designs a little more easily. This seemed like the best solution so far, to have a visual representation of the models and easily interchangeable.

Dogbone Universal Joint (Knuckle + C Coupler) Still a WIP.... Additional Supplies:
  • Carbon fiber arrow, sourced from walmart/amazon. Cheap arrows are fine. Approx 7-8mm OD
  • drill bit and small metal rod (tig rod). Size drillbit to fit OD of tig rod (1/16th used here, planning 1/8" in next version)
    • http://amzn.to/2mKWwES <- Carbon Arrows Cheap (~$2.5 per arrow)
    http://amzn.to/2meFQlK <- 1/16" Steel Tig Rod
    OR
    http://amzn.to/2mepcTd <- 1/16" Alum Tig Rod Instructions:
  • Shove knuckle onto end of a 7-8mm OD carbon fiber arrow, it was a tight fit.
  • Drilled a 1/16" hole through the end of the knuckle, perpendicular to arrow shaft and about centered on the knuckle.
  • Cut a 1/16" tig rod to length approx 23mm long
  • press tig rod through hole
    • Additional Notes:
    Printed this with some slower settings to get the print to turn out a little better. .2mm layer height is shown in photo for the knuckle while coupler was printed at .15mm height and it should be easily functional. Knuckle was designed to be printed as is, no support. I have a .5mm nozzle and it turned out very good. Nylon Bridge material will be much tougher for these parts to reduce wear. Further testing needed to determine lifespan. Coupler was designed for a 15x21x4mm bearing and was intended to be used in the RC car rear Diff. "rc_car_dogbone_universal_joint_v1.0.zip" file contains both STL and OpenScad files.

Main Drive Herringbone Gears Still a WIP... Initial test print of these was a success at .2mm height and 100% infill. They mesh well together. Originally I thought I'd be using a 12:72 gear ratio (6:1) powered by a 3000kv inrunner brushless motor. However upon further realization, to achieve even close to a 1/16th scale RC I'd have to size down my wheels (by half!) and that would allow me to use a different ratio, lending itself to a smaller spur gear. Next test print will be using a 16:36 gear ratio (2.25:1) on the main drive line and a 12:30 gear ratio (2.5:1) on the rear diff. Intending to adapt the main spur gear hub to an driveshaft mounting point, so I can actually power the main driveshaft. Still intending on using CF arrows (7-8mm OD) for the axles and driveshaft instead of printing. Caution: Rendering the large 72 teeth gear at the high quality settings ($fn around 500 and 10 iterations) takes a LONG time. On my biggest PC (8 core AMD-FX, 16GB ram, dual SSD in raid mirror with dual amd graphics cards) it took about 45 minutes to fully render and used about 12.5GB of ram. The gear library is the culprit of this large render time. Perhaps I'll attempt to improve their performance in the future, right now its not a limitation. original test print; changing to a smaller spur gear (36T) and will post pics when done.

Rear Differential - 12:30 Gear Ratio (2.5:1) I will be testing the print of this as a desktop model first. Scad file is mostly setup for size tweaks, but I got lazy towards the end and started hard-coding some difficult to calculate things. Its really not all that hard to figure out. I really just wanted to test print this and see how smooth it is, and any improvements before I start adding the final design. Realistically if I'm to meet any sort of close proximity to the RC scale choosen, I'll have to incorporate the entire rear diff housing into the full rear end with suspension mounting points and everything. Sadly this doesn't fit with my initial design concept of a more modular setup - having everything attach to the rear diff doesn't allow a quick swap like I was hoping. Perhaps I'll have to just keep an entire REAR END with suspension and everything for those time-critical instances when a swap is needed. This will need at least one full revision before its ready to hook into the other components in this 'thing'. You'll need (3) 15x21x4mm bearings for assembly as well as (3) properly sized "C" couplers (see attached scad/stl files), along with a 3 or 4mm OD "pin" for the spider gears and (2) screws to attach the axle spider gears to the C couplers via the square peg. The coupler will need a 15mm OD for the bearing_race_id value. I'm unsure of the depth at this point that the race will have to exist; once this is done printing I'll start to update the associated files so they are compatible. http://amzn.to/2njenPW <- 15x21x4mm Bearings I used. For a "SALT" test I'll be hooking this up to the main drive system, adding some resistance, and increasing ambient temperature to simulate real-world "racing" conditions. I've done some minimal research and found that I can most likely use a full-synthetic gear lube with the ABS and possibly the Nylon Bridge. This should greatly extend the lifespan of the parts. Otherwise graphite is another option but I like a liquid or grease personally. The gears are all intended to be printed in Nylon Bridge, as that's the toughest material I own currently. Initial tests will be with ABS however, as its much much faster to print with. Bearings Came in!!! Finally assembled a test!!! Sizes are good; needs spacers and will post a video! theoretical design; will print a test out. printed well enough at .2mm layer height. took about 2-3 hours for diff/gears in abs. queuing up the axle couplers next!

Front and rear motor mounts for the Zippa 250, designed so the motor wires exit down the arms. The front mounts are secured by a screw/nut  or ziptie through the hole on the tab on the top of the arm. You will need to drill another 3mm hole to allow this. The rear mounts are made to be a very tight push fit on the arms, trust me they are hard to get off so only only put them on when ready. The front motors can be mounted before you install the mount, but the rear mount needs a section of the arm removed so one of the screws can access the bottom of the motor. A 3 or 4mm drill or dremel should be the trick. The front motor screws will be tight against the arm but should push in no problem if you try to secure the motors after putting the mount on the arm. 
Print them the way they are in the thingyverse model images, so the inside clearance for the arm is a perfect square. The mounts are the same left to right so just print two of each.

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30-40%
Bushing some acetone over the outside of the mount will strengthen the laminations a bit more.

title: General purpose 40mm to 80 mm fan duct

description.text:
NOTE: V3.1 of the duct was just uploaded to correct a mistake in the 40mm fan 'grid' orientation which made it impossible to print without supports. The screenshots still show this version (3.0) but the STL will display the correct design (the 40mm grid rotated 45 degrees). This is a general purpose 40mm to 80mm fan adapter. This duct should enable you to usean 80mm fan in combinatie with anything that otherwise requires a 40mm fan, for example some extruder cooling fan duct. Designed to not need any supports. Whether or not a raft is required depends on your printer and settings, etc.
Using my printer on an aluminium heatbed with painters tape and '3D Lac' I still use a raft (the reason being that I'm new to 3D printing and have been having some issues with getting the print to properly stick to the bed without warp ruining it. I have been using ABS only so far, so I have no idea about the need for a raft when printing this in PLA).

DJI has released a new firmware for the Phantom which has a new take of feature. This new take of feature is optimized for transmitters with a spring loaded throttle lever (throttle lever jumps to the center when released). The current DJI Phantom transmitter is not equipped with this feature so with this throttle lever upgrade and a spring you can add this feature to your Phantom transmitter.
You still have to drill a 1.6 mm hole for the rotation axis.

My son and I are fans of the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game and as a new owner of a 3d Printer I decided to create a simple little holder for the location decks to hold the deck and display the location card at the same time in smaller space. 
The deck holder prints in two parts and then the top attaches to the bottom through basic pins and holes which allows it close fully and open up to a 110 degree angle. 
When you close the location take the location card out, close the holder and put the card on top with the closed side face up.  
The design is aimed at 3D printing and as such doesn't include a couple of features I'd like to see but it would make it hard to impossible to print and at the least require supports so simple is better. 
On my printer these latest versions print find and everything operates smoothly.  On some printers I can see where you might have to lightly sand the sides of the bottom depending on your resolution and tolerances. I've added a .1 or .2 clearance here and there to keep it all tight but able to move. 
The objects do pass STL checks and should slice without any problems.  
For my printer with my settings it takes about 90 minutes to print both.  You can speed that up of course by increasing layer height and print speeds.   
You'll need one pair of parts for each location you normally have in play.

Printer:

MendelMax 3

Rafts:

No

No

.2 - .3

20%

Notes: Nothing special, they should print fine with the above settings in the orientation they import in. The Top does have to small overhangs but I've ramped them and they print fine for me in PLA with cooling. You might have to clean those up if your printer has trouble with overhangs of 3mm or more. Using PVA or 3DEez I've not had to use brims or rafts. With ABS or some filament prone to curling you might need to use a raft or brim. If it does curl unless it's truly awful curling it shouldn't impact the functionality of the parts.
Designed in Studio Max and printed through Simplify3D and MatterControl.

title: Soft Jaws for Craftsman 51865 4.5" Bench Vise

description.text:
These soft jaws snap onto an early 1990's vintage Craftsman 51865 4.5" bench vise.  Print two, one for each jaw.  They fit pretty tight, but that's good.  I printed them at 40% infill, which seems okay, but you might want to print them out more solid, as your printer allows.
Here's the best part: If you ruin them, just print them again!

comments.text: Good idea wonder if this would work well with ninjaflex
comments.author: ragingrivers

comments.text: I've never worked with Ninjaflex, but I think it could work -- it would depend on what you're trying to do with it.  I mostly want these for securely holding pieces of wood without leaving teeth marks on them.  The PLA jaws work great for that.
comments.author: ragingrivers

title: Squares on Parabolic Base (solids of known cross section)

description.text: Model to demonstrate the "slicing" method for finding volumes of solids. Concept is building a square on the region bounded by x-axis, y-axis, and the parabola y=1-x^2.
